channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Explosions Damage Crimea Bridge as Russia Blames Ukraine for Attack
item.description: Russia accused Ukraine of hitting the Kerch Strait Bridge for the second time in 10 months, saying that two maritime drones had struck the bridge, an essential supply line for Russian troops.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Neil MacFarquhar and Haley Willis
item.media:credit: Crimea24TV, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A still from a video released by a Crimean news station showing a damaged section of the Kerch Strait Bridge on Monday.

item.title: Russia Stops Ukraine Grain Deal, Shaking World Food Markets
item.description: Moscow, which has repeatedly complained that the U.N.-brokered agreement is one-sided in Ukraine’s favor, said it could return to the deal if its demands were met.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Ivan Nechepurenko, Liz Alderman and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: SWIFT(Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication)
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukraine is a major exporter of foodstuffs, and Africa, in particular, relies on grain stored in silos like these, in Marianske, in the southern Dnipro region, in June.

item.title: Biden Invites Netanyahu to United States, Easing Tensions
item.description: The invitation to the Israeli prime minister came on the eve of a visit to the White House by Isaac Herzog, the Israeli president.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: President Isaac Herzog of Israel and President Biden during a meeting in the Oval Office in October. Mr. Herzog is visiting Washington again this week.

item.title: Where Is Qin Gang, China’s Foreign Minister? Beijing Won’t Say.
item.description: Qin Gang has not made a public appearance in three weeks. The Communist Party’s habitual secrecy around top officials has fueled speculation over the reasons for his absence.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and David Pierson
item.media:credit: Leah Millis/Agence France-Presse Via Getty Images
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Qin Gang of China, right, with Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken in Beijing last month. Mr. Qin’s last reported engagements were on June 25.

item.title: Wildfire in Canary Islands Forces Thousands to Evacuate
item.description: The blaze on the island of La Palma has driven some 4,000 residents from their homes and burned about 10,000 acres. Wildfires also broke out in Greece.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A wildfire that started Saturday on La Palma in the Canary Islands left a stand of charred trees on Monday, as more than 500 firefighters sought to bring it under control.

item.title: In a Bid to Curb Migrants, Europe Strikes a Deal With Tunisia
item.description: After the deadliest shipwreck in years in the Mediterranean, E.U. officials will pay Tunisia to prevent migrants from setting to sea.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Migrants from sub-Saharan African, who said they had been abandoned in the desert by the Tunisian authorities, arriving at a shelter in Libya on Sunday.

item.title: Far From the Front, They Stand in Honor of Ukraine
item.description: The city of Chernivtsi in western Ukraine has been spared the mayhem of the Russian invasion. But like other towns in the region, it is doing its part, and has become, in effect, a back office of the war effort.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents and city workers observe a moment of silence in the central square in Chernivtsi, in southwest Ukraine, to honor those killed in the war.

item.title: What’s Next for Israel’s Judicial Overhaul?
item.description: Israeli lawmakers are advancing parts of a contentious plan by the right-wing government to reduce the power of the Supreme Court. A final vote is expected by early next week.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Israelis demonstrating on Saturday in Tel Aviv against a government plan to overhaul the judiciary.

item.title: Iran Steps Up Policing of Women Who Defy Strict Dress Code
item.description: The country’s morality police disappeared from the streets late last year as the authorities tried to calm anti-government protests. Now, patrols are once again watching for violators.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:description: Iranian police officers patrolling the streets of the capital, Tehran, on Sunday. It was unclear whether the authorities were again deploying the morality police, or were requiring the regular police to take on that role.

item.title: More Than 50 Whales Die After Being Stranded in Scotland
item.description: Only one pilot whale survived out of the 55 beached on the Isle of Lewis in northwest Scotland on Sunday. It was the largest mass stranding in the region in over a decade.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che
item.media:credit: Cristina McAvoy/British Divers Marine Life Rescue
item.media:description: More than 50 pilot whales died on Sunday after being stranded on a beach in Scotland.

item.title: Kerry Says U.S. and China Must Set Aside Politics to Tackle Climate Change
item.description: John Kerry, President Biden’s climate envoy, is in Beijing for three days of talks between the world’s largest emitters of greenhouse gas pollution.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: John Kerry, the U.S. special presidential envoy for climate, meeting with his Chinese counterpart, Xie Zhenhua, in Beijing on Monday.

item.title: Riots in France Highlight a Vicious Cycle Between Police and Minorities
item.description: Calls to overhaul the police go back decades. But violent episodes of police enforcement continue. So do violent outpourings on the street.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times

item.title: A National Treasure, Tarnished: Can Britain Fix Its Health Service?
item.description: As it turns 75, the N.H.S., a proud symbol of Britain’s welfare state, is in the deepest crisis of its history.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A knee operation at the King George Hospital in Ilford, England. More than 7.4 million people in England are waiting for medical procedures.

item.title: After Suffering Heavy Losses, Ukrainians Paused to Rethink Strategy
item.description: Early in the counteroffensive, Ukraine lost as much as 20 percent of its weapons and armor. The rate dropped as the campaign slowed and commanders shifted tactics.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes, Andrew E. Kramer and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian recruits in the Azov regiment disembarking from an American tactical vehicle during training in March.

item.title: Moscow Warns Ukraine Against Shipping Grain Across the Black Sea Without Its Consent
item.description: The Kremlin’s comments came after Ukraine’s leader called for the shipments to continue despite Russia’s withdrawal from a landmark grain deal.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cargo vessel being filled with grain in the Black Sea port of Pivdennyi, Ukraine, last August.

item.title: U.S. Nuclear-Capable Sub Visits South Korea for First Time in Decades
item.description: The submarine made a port call as part of Washington’s effort to show its commitment to defending its East Asian ally.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: In this image released by U.S. Strategic Command, the submarine Kentucky is transiting the Hood Canal in 2017.

item.title: North Korea Detains U.S. Citizen After Unauthorized Border Crossing
item.description: The man is the first known American to be held in North Korean custody since​ Bruce Byron Lowrance​ was detained for a month after illegally entering the country from China in 2018.​
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun

item.title: As China Bakes in Record Heat, John Kerry Presses Beijing on Climate Change
item.description: The extreme heat wave choking China has become a talking point for John Kerry, President Biden’s climate envoy, in his meetings with officials in Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Lisa Friedman
item.category: Great Hall of the People (Beijing, China)
item.media:description: Tuesday was the 27th day this year that the city of Beijing has recorded temperatures above 95 degrees Fahrenheit — the highest number of days in one year since records began.

item.title: Spanish Vote Threatens Efforts to Recover Franco’s Victims
item.description: Spain’s left-wing government has tried to accelerate exhumations of mass graves left from the dictatorship. If it wins Sunday’s election, the right may end that.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Samuel Aranda
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Descendants of victims of Franco’s firing squads at the cemetery in Paterna, Spain, where 2,200 people were executed.

item.title: Yiddish Is Alive and Well in Melbourne, Australia
item.description: Australia has the largest proportion of Holocaust survivors of any country besides Israel. In Melbourne, some of their descendants are leading the way to preserve the Yiddish language.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Christina Simons for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kindergarten students learning Yiddish at Sholem Aleichem College in Melbourne, Australia.

item.title: Herzog of Israel to Meet With Biden Amid U.S. Unease With Netanyahu
item.description: President Biden’s meeting with Isaac Herzog and accompanying declarations of support for Israel have masked strains between the White House and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Isaac Herzog of Israel plans to meet with President Biden at the White House on Tuesday and then address a joint session of Congress on Wednesday.

item.title: Israelis Protest Against Judicial Overhaul
item.description: Thousands of Israelis blocked roads and demonstrated over Benjamin Netanyahu’s plans to limit the power of the judiciary.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: A protest in Tel Aviv on Tuesday against the government’s judicial overhaul plan.

item.title: Victoria, Australia, Backs Out as Host of 2026 Commonwealth Games
item.description: The state of Victoria cited budget issues in deciding not to stage the multisports competition, originally known as the British Empire Games, raising questions about the event’s fading prestige.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Thawing relations between Israel and the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu chairs a cabinet meeting in Jerusalem on Monday.

item.title: Mandela Goes From Hero to Scapegoat as South Africa Struggles
item.description: Nelson Mandela is revered worldwide and celebrated on July 18, his birthday. But at home, a younger generation is disillusioned with the country, his party and the anti-apartheid leader, too.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Gulshan Khan
item.media:credit: Gulshan Khan for The New York Times
item.media:description: South Africa’s s largest monument to Nelson Mandela: a 30-foot bronze statue in Pretoria, South Africa’s executive capital.

item.title: A Current War Collides With the Past: Remnants of World War II in Ukraine
item.description: World War II has been an ideological battlefield in today’s war in Ukraine, and it is cropping up on the actual battlefield as well.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oleksandr Shkalikov, a Ukrainian tank driver, scrambles over the surreal landscape revealed after the Kakhovka dam was destroyed.

item.title: Modi and India’s Diaspora: A Complex Love Affair Making Global Waves
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi has tried to fuse his image to the economic and political power of Indians abroad. They voice both pride and worry in return.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India at a rally in an arena in Sydney, in May.

item.title: Corrections: July 18, 2023
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, July 18, 2023.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: China Engages as Its Economy Sputters
item.description: Also, an attack on a bridge between Russia and Crimea.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A market in Suzhou, China, in April.

item.title: Mystery Object Is Found on Remote Beach in Western Australia
item.description: The authorities said the cylindrical object, which was found about 155 miles north of Perth, did not pose a risk to the public, but they have yet to identify it.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: A metal cylinder that was found on a beach in Western Australia is at least two meters, or about 6 feet 6 inches, tall, according to local news reports.

item.title: Wagner Convoy Arrives at Camp in Belarus
item.description: The troop movements are the private company’s biggest — and most public — showing since its failed rebellion in Russia last month.
item.dc:creator: Christoph Koettl and Christiaan Triebert

item.title: What We Know About the Crimea Bridge Attack
item.description: Monday’s strike was the second in less than a year to target the Kerch Strait Bridge, which holds strategic and symbolic importance for Russia.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

item.title: A Positive Covid Milestone
item.description: In a sign that the pandemic really is over, the total number of Americans dying each day is no longer historically abnormal.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A memorial exhibit at Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn commemorating the more than 1.1 million American’s who died during the pandemic.

item.title: House Committee Targets U.C. Berkeley Program for China Ties
item.description: A House select committee is requesting more information about a university collaboration that it said could help China gain access to cutting-edge research.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Marlena Sloss for The New York Times
item.media:description: A House select committee has requested that the University of California, Berkeley, provide extensive documents and information about a research partnership with Chinese entities.

item.title: Russia Ends Participation in Black Sea Grain Deal
item.description: The Kremlin terminated an agreement that had allowed Ukraine to export its grain by sea despite a wartime blockade, a deal seen as essential to keeping global food prices stable.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Ivan Nechepurenko and Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Harvesting wheat in the town of Malokaterynivka in Ukraine’s southern Zaporizhzhia region last week.

item.title: Russia’s Embassy in Washington is enmeshed in a different kind of war.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Britain’s troubled health service.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A knee operation at the King George Hospital in Ilford, England. More than 7.4 million people in England are waiting for medical procedures.

item.title: Why Does Every Women’s World Cup City Have Two Names?
item.description: A concerted effort to say Indigenous names correctly, and tell the stories behind them, will show up in stadiums in New Zealand and Australia.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A waka, a Māori canoe, in Wellington, which is also known as Te Whanganui-a-Tara.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: U.S. and China Restart Climate Talks
item.description: Also, the G20 finance ministers prepare to meet in India, China targets Canadian politicians and cricket rises in Texas.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: John Kerry met with Xie Zhenhua, Mr. Kerry’s Chinese counterpart, at the U.N. climate summit in Sharm el Sheikh, Egypt, last year.

item.title: Remembering the Dead
item.description: Fans are saying goodbye, again, to the band that was once the Grateful Dead.
item.dc:creator: Tom Wright-Piersanti
item.media:credit: Peter Fisher for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dead & Company fans in New York in June.

item.title: Black Sea Grain Deal in Balance as Deadline Looms Again
item.description: Russia has repeatedly threatened to pull out of the wartime export agreement, which has helped stabilize global grain prices and avert famines. The latest deadline to renew it is Monday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Vivek Shankar
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Harvesting last year outside Chasiv Yar, Ukraine. When the country’s crops were blocked from the world market, wheat prices soared.

item.title: Benjamin Netanyahu Leaves Hospital
item.description: The Israeli prime minister spent Saturday night in a hospital after feeling dizziness, but was said to be in “excellent condition” on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, 73, was admitted Saturday to the Sheba Medical Center, a leading hospital near Tel Aviv.

item.title: As Iraq Tries to Chill Critics, Its Newest Target Is Social Media
item.description: New regulations on “degrading content” are part of a broader campaign to silence independent voices.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Dozens of Iraqis gathered in Tahrir Square in Baghdad in January to demand that the government release relatives who disappeared during protests in 2019.

item.title: As Climate Shocks Multiply, Designers Seek Holy Grail: Disaster-Proof Homes
item.description: The homebuilding industry has been slow to adopt changes that can better protect against extreme weather. Some architects are showing what’s possible.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:credit: Bryan Tarnowski for The New York Times
item.media:description: The home of Joel and Deborah Veazey in southwest Louisiana, a geodesic dome build to withstand hurricane-force winds.

item.title: Fossils Where They Don’t Belong? Maybe We Just Didn’t Look Hard Enough.
item.description: Researchers are fiercely debating whether claims about the origins of mammals result from a bias toward Northern Hemisphere fossil sites.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Ham
item.category: Alcheringa: An Australasian Journal of Palaeontology
item.media:description: The jawbone of Ambondro mahabo, a species that was 25 million years older than any mammal of its kind ever found.

item.title: Small, Hidden and Deadly: Mines Stymie Ukraine’s Counteroffensive
item.description: To gain ground, Ukrainian forces have to make their way through a variety and density of Russian land mines they never imagined.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Antitank mines littering the ground at a former Russian position in the village of Novodarivka, which was recently recaptured by Ukraine’s 110th Territorial Defense Brigade and other forces.

item.title: Carlos Alberto Montaner, Prominent Critic of Castro’s Cuba, Dies at 80
item.description: After fleeing the island in 1961, he became one of the leading voices of opposition against the country’s Communist dictatorship.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Carlos Alberto Montaner during an interview with Agence France-Presse in 2007. Throughout his career as a writer and political commentator, Mr. Montaner developed a reputation as a fierce critic of the Castro regime.

item.title: Israeli Reservists Threaten Mass Resignations if Judicial Plan Proceeds
item.description: Military reserves are critical to Israel’s operational readiness. Reservists are again using that leverage against the government’s effort to curb judicial power.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: In March, Israeli military reservists protested plans by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s right-wing government to overhaul the judicial system. They are renewing those protests now.

item.title: Netanyahu Says He’s ‘Very Well’ After Being Rushed to Hospital
item.description: Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, said he was feeling better on Saturday after feeling dizzy and rushing to the hospital. Mr. Netanyahu, 73, is currently facing one of the most testing phases of his political career.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel this month in Jerusalem.

item.title: Poland Doesn’t Want Migrants, but These Foreign Workers Are Welcome
item.description: A tiny village is taking in 6,000 laborers from Asia. They are needed by a petroleum company controlled by the right-wing government, which has vowed to keep migrants out.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: A housing compound built for 6,000 foreign workers near the village of Biala, Poland, which has 200 residents. The country’s main political parties do not want to be seen as soft on immigration, but they also want the economy to keep growing.

item.title: Appleby Horse Fair Draws Thousands of Gypsies and Travellers
item.description: The Appleby Horse Fair draws tens of thousands of Gypsies and Irish Travellers each year to a rural patch of England to celebrate their culture. Our photographer spent four days there.
item.dc:creator: Mary Turner and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: A highlight of the Appleby fair.

item.title: Reconsidering the Staycation
item.description: You don’t necessarily have to travel to experience the benefits of a summer vacation.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Frank Gehry Returns to the Streets of His Canadian Childhood
item.description: The renowned architect was back in Toronto for the start of construction on his second project in the city where he was born and raised.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Frank Gehry, the architect, at the site of his latest Toronto project last month.

item.title: Russia Doing ‘Everything’ to Stop Ukraine’s Counteroffensive, Zelensky Says
item.description: The Ukrainian leader has secured new weapons pledges, but it was not clear when the aid would arrive, or how consequential it would be on the battlefield.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Recruits with Ukraine’s 3rd Brigade during a training exercise in the eastern Donetsk region on Saturday.

item.title: Canadian Politicians Who Criticize China Become Its Targets
item.description: As China increases its reach in diaspora communities, Chinese Canadian politicians in Vancouver are the focus of Chinese state interference in Canadian politics.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Alana Paterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kenny Chiu, a former member of Parliament representing a district outside Vancouver, appears to have been targeted by supporters of China because of his public criticisms of China’s human rights record.

item.title: Kerry Heads to China for Long-Awaited Climate Talks: What to Know
item.description: John Kerry travels to Beijing for three days of talks, as the world’s two biggest economies, and two biggest polluters, try to cooperate on climate action.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: John Kerry, the U.S. special envoy for climate change, is set to arrive in Beijing on Sunday to restart climate negotiations with the Chinese government.

item.title: Floods and Landslides Kill at Least 40 in South Korea
item.description: With at least 40 people dead, the current monsoon season is already proving to be a particularly dangerous one in South Korea, with rain forecast to continue.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: In Cheongju, a city in central South Korea, roads were underwater on Friday.

item.title: Putin Says Wagner Can Keep Fighting for Russia, but Without Prigozhin
item.description: As Russia’s president reasserts control after a failed mutiny, he wants to sideline the Wagner leader while keeping its fighters — who have started training troops in Belarus — working for him.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in a photo released on Friday by Russian state media.

item.title: Visitors Briefly Trapped at Former Home of Agatha Christie
item.description: In a moment of literary irony, visitors were stranded at Greenway House, where the mystery novelist once lived, when a fallen tree blocked the road.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: English writer Agatha Christie, and her husband Max E.L. Mallowan, pose in March 1946 on the grounds of their holiday home, Greenway House.

item.title: South Africa Grapples With Putin’s Plan to Attend BRICS Summit
item.description: An arrest warrant for the Russian leader from the International Criminal Court has created a diplomatic quandary ahead of an August summit.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Naledi Pandor, left, South Africa’s foreign minister, and her Russian counterpart, Sergey V. Lavrov, in Cape Town last month.
